item.title: A Visit to a Town Under Fire in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: We go to a town in Eastern Ukraine that is close to the front lines and under constant fire. Russians are advancing in Eastern Ukraine as Ukrainian forces run low on ammunition and weapons.

item.title: A State Department official warns Israel of 'major' reputational damage in Gaza war
item.description: Assistant Secretary of State Bill Russo told Israeli officials last week the Gaza war is damaging Israel's global reputation, potentially lasting a generation, according to a readout obtained by NPR.

item.title: New Indiana law requires professors to promote 'intellectual diversity' to keep tenure
item.description: A new Indiana law requires professors to promote "intellectual diversity" to receive tenure. Critics worry the measure will dissuade academics from staying in the state.

item.title: Deaths and injuries are reported after an attack on a concert hall outside Moscow
item.description: Reports from Moscow say gunmen attacked a concert hall outside the capital. A fire broke out after the attack. According to Tass news agency, some people remain trapped in the building.

item.title: Catherine, Princess of Wales, announces she is undergoing treatment for cancer

item.title: If you recently sold your home, you might get part of your realtor fee back
item.description: A settlement by the National Realtors Association promises to change the way real estate agents are compensated. It could spell an end to 6% commissions, which are higher than people pay elsewhere.
